answers.answer: I have no idea who does what, but why not call the endo's office and ask? Also, if he/she (endo) does the biopsy, has he/she done many before? Some endos treat/are interested in primarily diabetes, so you want to be sure you're going to one who's knowledgable in thyroid issues.When you say head and neck doctor, do you mean an ENT (ear, nose and throat)?Good luck :-)

Endo should be able to do the two FNA, however make sure he has done many of them.  if surgery is need, then a thyroid surgeon who has done a lot of thyroid surgery per year should be sought.October is breast cancer awareness month.The Third Friday in OCTOBER is National Mammography DayOn this day, or throughout the month, radiologists provide discounted or free  Mammograms.  Go  here http://www.nbcam.org/ to give free mammogram to underprivileged woman every day, its free.The Silent Killer: Inflammatory Breast Cancer http://www.komotv.com/ibc/and http://www.ibcsupport.org/

Thanks for your responses.  I called the endo office.  I was told that they do do biopsies of the thyroid, sometimes in the office and sometimes in the hospital. (?)  The head and neck is actually an oncologist.

question: I have a question.  I have thyroid nodules/lesion in both sides of my thyroid.  I have posted questions here before but not this question.  My labs are within normal limits.  My PCP set me up with an appointment with endo but not until 11/30.  I am being urged by a cousin and a friend (both nurses) and another friend (nurse practitioner) to call my PCP and ask if I should have an appointment with head and neck surgeon instead.  My PCP is talking about biopsy, but that's not something endo will do, is it?  Should I be a "squeaky wheel" and ask about head and neck over endo?  Anyone been in this kind of situation?  Do endos do biopsies or would I be sent on to head and neck anyway?  I already feel like my PCP office is getting tired of me because it's not something they are going to be "treating".
title: I have a question.
